thread.title: Police abuse victims encouraged to file raps
thread.title_full: Police abuse victims encouraged to file raps

title: Police abuse victims encouraged to file raps
text:
Police abuse victims encouraged to file raps By Emmanuel Tupas (The Philippine Star)   
MANILA, Philippines - Victims of police abuse may start filing complaints next week with the Camp Crame-based Counter-Intelligence Task Force (CITF), the unit formed to rid the Philippine National Police (PNP) of scalawags and misfits. 
PNP chief Director General Ronald dela Rosa said he expects the CITF to be operational possibly beginning tomorrow, with its headquarters in a building once occupied by the disbanded Anti-Illegal Drugs Group. 
“Maybe next week, probably Monday it will be launched and can entertain complaints and information about rogue cops,” Dela Rosa told reporters on Friday. 
Dela Rosa also urged the public not to hesitate to report police officers involved in irregularities. “All those involved in illegal drugs, smuggling, extortion and abuses. It will be covered,” he said. 
The creation of the CITF came in the wake of discovery that rogue policemen kidnapped and murdered Korean businessman Jee Ick-joo. The Korean was kidnapped in Pampanga and killed inside the PNP headquarters at Camp Crame. 
Initial investigation showed Jee had been dead by the time his wife paid his captors P5 million ransom for his release.   
Dela Rosa would later say some members of the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) were involved in Jee’s kidnap-slay. 
He reassigned one company or about 70 Special Action Force (SAF) commandos to serve as CITF enforcement unit.
